relation: Rocky shore (intertidal), Nrth side of Whitley bay, Northumberland
Hera Site of wreck of the HERA, Gull Rock E of Nare Head Cornwall,
Weasal Diving Hole Weasal Diving Hole, Eyemouth, Scotland.
St Abbs Big Green Carr/Amphitheatre St Abbs, Scotland.
St Mary's Lighthouse St Mary's lighthouse, North side of Whitley bay, Northumberland.
Rocky shore. Sand in places at low water
West end of Praa Sands, Cornwall
Goodrington Sands on shore in front of Seashore Centre
Lindisfarne St Mary's Local Nature Reserve 1km north of Whitley Baye.g. South coast of Lindisfarne, near the harbour.
Hat rock, up to 37 meters deep, underwater visibility 9 meters.
Wreck of the King Cadwallan, Scilly Isles, on the Hard Lewis Rocks. 36 meters deep, underwater visibility 8-9 meters, slight current. SE 5. Sea temperature 13 degrees.

Wreck of the Italia off St. Agnes, Scilly Isles. 39 meters deep, underwater visibility >12 meters, water temperature 13 degrees. No water speed and weather calm with variable 1!! Afternoon dive. Wreck broken up on rocks.
Wreck of the HMS Scylla, Whitsand Bay, Cornwall
Wreck of the HMS Scylla, Whitsand Bay, Cornwall.
Babbacombe bay - few metres off shore
Freathy Cliff, in a large rockpool
Whitepoint, Cobh, Cork Harbour (on Great Island opposite Haulbowline Island - west of the old jetty)
France Aimee Near the wreck of the France Aimee on the east side of the isle of wight
Combesgate Combesgate, north end Woolacombe Bay.
Oxwich Bay, right hand side on and around rocks leading to Oxwich point, Gower
Oxwich Point Oxwich Point, Gower - 3/4 of way along from beach
On the sand at low tide at the base of the shingle bank along Dungeness point.
Dog beach Rocky shore, south east coast of cornwall. Dog beach, Looe.
Coombesgate, Woolacombe 2 sandy bays divided by small rocky headlands with extensive rocks at low tide.
Blakeney long shingle and sandy beach

Eastbourne Pier The pier at Eastbourne. Sandy beach below shingle with some soft bedrock with pools. In addition to the list Mactra stultrom common, as were hydroids (unidentified on the pier structure)
Polzeath, Cornwall Found large, live, common starfish, at 1pm. Moved animal to deeper rock pool to await high tide.
Farne Islands Rocky islands 20 minutes by boat from Seahouses, Northumberland. Small islands 5 minutes north west of the largest Island

Cow Gap, Beachy Head Sussex Rock pools and sandstone area. Area of sand and some mud/ sand patches amongst the boulders and other rocks. Jaera sp also seen. Pools near the cliff had the seaweed Dumontia incrassata and shells of Mactra stultorum were also found (neither listed in DB)
Redgate Beach, Babbacombe, Torquay, UK Rocky shore, South East facing beach
Hope Gap, Sussex Chalk platform at low tide (1.2m) Several unidentified seaweeds seen and two scale worms (?Harmothoe impar). ALso Halurus equisetifolius which does not appear in the list
Hallsands, South Devon Shallow dive 4-5m just off South Hallsands
Eastbourne Chalk platform in the east and sandy areas at low tide with soft rock and rock pools.

Corton Sand and shingle beach with occassional areas of exposed hard substratum comprising 'soft' sedimentary rock in which shallow pools have formed. Groynes and wooden defenders situated near the mid tide mark behind which pools have formed.
Saunton, N Devon Rocks between base of Saunton Down & Saunton Sands
Cart Gap, nr Happisburgh Near to high tide mark. Sandy shore with some gravel. Near groynes with barnacles and mussels.
10 per square metre in some places. 2 hours after high tide, stranded on beach, some dead, some alive.
Small specimens on course sand at 6mtrs
Found whilst rock pooling on lower shore during extremely low tide. Some sitting amongst kelp fronds rather than beneath rocks.
approx. 25cm dia. seen in rockpool digesting a limpet with it's stomach turned inside out
Both common and spiny starfish common throughout dive.
Generally present draped over wreckage and associated rocks, up to 15 cm long.
Draped over wreck corners and further up into the shallows on the rocks. Up to 12 cm long.
Many seen - common sight throughout dive.
Present in large numbers all over the wreck.
Seen on a rock. Smallish, approx. 6cm from armtip to armtip.
Seen under rocks and seaweed, ranging in size from .5 - 4 cm.
plentiful on sand and in pools
Under weed at base rocks low shore, about 15cm diam
orange and purplish varieties of all sizes
many small ones under stones and boulders clustering together
On the sand at the base of the shingle bank.
many dead starfish washed up after storm
50cm in diameter in crevice, green upper, orange underneath eating a limpet
In a crevice at low tide about 9cm long. Mid-shore.
Up to 20cm, in various locations on edge of pool on the sandy shore
Most were dried out in the high shore line.
One attacked by juvenile Herring Gulls
On rocks from surface down to 12m. Juveniles at 1cm across to 8cm adults
Single live individual found under boulder
reasonably large individual under rock of middle shore
Found under stone about 80mm wide (so a small individual)
Seafloor was carpeted in common starfish between the rocky areas. All sorts of sizes and condition - some with five arms, others with a less
c.80mm in size at the low tide mark
various location usually on rocks, also observed very small specimens but was unable to establish exact species
